bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 9, 1875

div1.p: Reed expresses his love for his dispersed family, and notes that it has been one year since he met her. Reed will delay taking his medical exam.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 9, 1875
div1.p:
It may appear a little late in the
day, but I will venture to wish you “a happy,
thrice happy New year”! may it bring you
much happiness and many friends!
The old year passed away so calmly and
quickly and the New Year followed in its
footsteps so softly, that I was not
aware of the change for several hours
thereafter. In fact, balmly sleep had made
me totally oblivious to all changes.
I can remember the time when I would
have been ashamed to make such
an acknowledgement; for it was
my custom to sit and watch the
hands of the old clock as they slowly,
but surely, neared the hour of midnight,
and when that important moment, at
last, arrived, I would jump to my feet
and give three hearty cheers for the
New Year; or, if influenced by a more
sober mood, would remain on “ben-
ded knee”, silently praying that my
record for the New Year might be
better and more acceptable than it
had been during the old.year. But, of
late, I have lost much interest in bid-
ding farewell to the “old” or in welcom-
ing the “New.” The night of the 31st of December, as far as I am concerned,
has no more importance attached
to it than any other night in the year.
I have been absent from home and
friends, so many years, that I even
forget to celebrate Christmas, a day
which in times gone by was to me the
pleasantest of all. Very many times
circumstances have been such as to
prevent me from entering into the joys
of the occassion, as happened during
the Christmas just passed- I had to
work and leave to others less arduous
duties. Yet this is not such as I would
have it be. It is far, very far from
expressing my desires. I think there
is no more fitting occassion than
Christmas week for the reunion of
the scattered members of a family,
and for the renewal of those pledges
of friendship and love which are so
sweet to every heart. In this “vale of
tears” where there are so many burdens to bear,
so many annoying trivialties to harrass,
it is but following our natural impulses
to long for some hour or day when we
can cast aside all cares and exchange
our frowns for smiles, our sighs for
songs. I have much cause to fear that
such an occassion will never again
present itself in my father's family-
Like unto the chaff before the winds, we
are scattered even unto “the four cor-
ners of the earth”! Still mingled with
these feelings of regret, I yet possess
some consolation, some comfort- I
have a vivid consciousness of a
love for my pbrothers and sisters as
pure as the love of angels, over which
nor time nor distance has any power;
of a veneration for my parents as
noble as the noblest; of a memory
of my sainted mother as pure as the crys-
tals in Heaven's great dome; yes, thank
God, so holy and bright is this memory
that neither storm, nor fire, nor flood,
nor time, nor eternity can ever dim
its lustre! These things are left to
me as “my portion” -- these are my
treasures which I hide in my heart
of hearts and defy the powers of worlds
known and unknown to rob me of one
“jot or tittle” of their preciousness!
Possessed of such jewels as these, though
lost in earth's dreariest desert, I could
yet know some happiness.

But to retrace my steps a little.
I was saying that the old year's de-
parture was by me unobserved, yet
when I awoke on the morrow and found
that such was the fact, many thoughts
flooded my brain-thoughts similar
to those expressed by yourself. Surely, if
you have occassion for sadness, I
should forever hide my head from the
light of day. Truly, I cannot recall
a year so full of sorrow, and yet, in
some respects, so happy, as the past
one. Paradoxical as this may sound,
it is nevertheless true. Anguish,
remorse! oh! feeble words to express
what I have almost daily experienced.
God, Himself, can only know what
tortures I have borne; by what “dark
waters” I have sat! And in this mid-
night of sorrow among the stars that
shed a gladsome ray upon my
path, there was one particularly
bright and beautiful- Can you not
imagine to what I refer? Even to your
acquaintance, which I trust may yet
grow into true friendship. This re-
minds me that just one year has passed
since I first met you. Yes, one year
ago, I visited your little city. I only
trust that before another year has
elapsed, I may possess your esteem
more than I do at present; that I
may conduct myself so fairly and
honestly, that should anyone say, in
your presence, that my words are
flattering & my statements deceptive,
you would be prepared to deny the
assertion, or, at least, to know in your
own heart, that it was false.
Since then the old year witnessed our
acquaintance, I still cling fondly to
its memory with all its griefs and burdens-
Its dark days I blot out from my re-
membrance, to-night, and only recall its
brightest moments. Thank Heaven, I can
and do forget the things of the Past-
My broken resolutions, my shattered
hopes, all, all, I bury, and begin the
New Year as free from care as a bird!
Did I say free from care? Ah! no! one thought
bids me recall that expression, and that is
my lack of religion. Though in my early
childhood it was my privilege to daily
kneel and receive instruction at the feet
of a Christian mother, now sainted; and
though during my boyhood it was my
good fortune to be surrounded by
Christian influences; and from boyhood
to manhood to be guided by the wise
consels of a kind father; yet I find my-
self, to-night, far from leading a pious
life. Would to Heaven that I could utter
other words! But since I begun the Old
Year by making so many good resolutions,
& e're it ended, had broken them all, I
shall begin the present year with not so
much as one. Perhaps it will be just
as well. My only aim shall be to seek
after truth and knowledge; to avoid
the evil & cleave to the good, and in all
things, as far as in I am able, to conduct
myself as a Christian man and a Southern
gentleman. To follow the words of the Poet;
“who misses or who wins the prize,
Go lose or conquer as you can;
But if you fall or if you rise,
Be each, pray God, a gentleman”!

I was glad to hear that
Messrs Longfellow and Bryant arrived
safely and proved acceptable. I am not
sufficiently well acquainted with the wri-
tings of either author to be able to refer
to their best poems, but if my memory
serves me correctly, there is a short
poem by Bryant called the “Rivulet”
which struck me as being very beautiful
& expressive. I know that I read it over
& over again & each reading pleased
me the more. If you will refer to it, I
think you will agree with me as to
its beauty. There were many others by
the same Author which I much admired,
but my treacherous memory does not
permit me to recall them.
You will perceive, by noticing the
number & st. from which I write, that
I have changed my residence. This
occurred somewhat suddenly, though
not unexpectedly. There had been an
undercurrent of dissatisfaction between
myself & my most worthy landlady, dating
from the time of my sickness. But I
had hoped to avoid any open disturbance,
& bore with Job-like patience every un-
pleasant word or act. This course of pro-
ceedings conveyed no lessons of instruction
to my landlady, but rather led her to think
that I was a meek mortal upon whose
neck she could place her foot, with
impunity. Poor, deluded creature!
She little dreamed that she was walking
through a powder magazine with a lighted
match in her hand! But she knows bet-
ter to-day, for I opened my mouth, at
last, and she knows, this morning,
what I think of Homeopathy, Unitarian-
ism, Abolitionism, Spiritualism ect, for
these are all included in her creed!
But I leave her to an ignominious fate!
I am very pleasantly located, so pleas-
antly located that I really think that
I am ready & willing that you should
not abandon the use of “metaphor” in
your letters! I am sure that I could
understand you, freed, as I am, from
my former annoyances. I should state
that, out of consideration for the Board of
Health, I have had my examination postponed
to the 8th day of February- You will please excuse
all miserable scribbling, since I wrote with
the paper on my lap.

closer.salute:
I remain, very truly,
your friend,
closer.seg:
P.S.
The paper on which I write is so
transparent, that, in order to protect
the contents of my letter from the
gaze of the curious (for there are such)
I have thought it best to wrap
about it an extra sheet.
Sincerely yours,
W. R.
